newsitem.title: USA: Calif. panel submits $540mln renewable energy plan.
newsitem.headline: Calif. panel submits $540mln renewable energy plan.

text.p: California's Energy Commission on Tuesday outlined a plan to allocate $540 million among the state's alternative energy firms to help them compete in the deregulated electricity market.
The commission recommended that the funds go to producers of wind, solar, geothermal, biomass and other forms of renewable energy.

"Renewable energy is an important part of California's energy mix," Commissioner Michal Moore said in a statement. "The funding ensures that energy resources beneficial from an environmental standpoint are afforded a competitive edge."

The report proposes the allocation of $243 million to existing renewable technologies. These include biomass, solar thermal, wind, geothermal, small hydro, digester gas, municipal solid waste, and land fill gas technologies.
New technologies will receive $162 million, and emerging technologies $54 million. A program to build a customer-driven market for renewables would receive $81 million.

The $540 million in funding will be collected from existing investor-owned utility ratepayers from 1998 to 2002, the commission said. The commission said its report will be presented to the state legislature this week.
